Burkard |president = Mark Mortenson |curator = Kathryn Leacock |publictransit = |network = |website = }} '''Buffalo Museum of Science''' is a [[science]] museum located at [[Martin Luther King, Jr. Park]] in [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], [[New York]] [[United States|USA]], northeast of the downtown district, near the [[New York State Route 33|Kensington Expressway]]. The historic building was designed by [[August Esenwein]] and [[James A. Johnson (architect)|James A. Johnson]] and opened in 1929. The attractions include [[animal]]s, [[astronomy]], the science of technology, and more about science. ==Exhibitions== ===Connections=== Connections is an interactive gallery featuring 90 minute sessions that allow visitors to experience hands-on learning. Programs include exploring interconnectedness of all things, types of [[energy]], cyclic patterns in the [[universe]], the worlds of [[color]] and [[light]], the [[water cycle]], [[nature]]'s [[biodiversity]], and [[rocks]] and [[minerals]]. <ref>Buffalo Museum of Science Website, http://www.sciencebuff.org/exhibitions.php, 23 September 2008</ref> ===Explorations=== Explorations is an interactive gallery for children aged 2 to 7 featuring new themes every month. ===Dinosaurs & Co.=== Dinosaurs & Co. is a collection of [[fossils]] organized into four sections: The Early [[Sea]]s, Conquest of the Land, The Age of [[Dinosaurs]] and The Age of [[Mammals]]. [[Biological specimen|Specimens]] include 50-million-year-old [[birds]], [[feathers]] and [[flowers]], the earliest known land plant, a [[trilobite]] trapped in a [[seashell]] nearly 400 million years ago, a cast of a [[Tyrannosaurus Rex]] skull, a [[Triceratops]] cast, and [[Allosaurus fragilis]]. ===Our Place in Space=== Our Place is Space features an [[astronomy]] gallery with five different themed areas. Areas include the subjects of the neighboring [[planet]]s and [[constellations]], [[meteorite]]s, a look at [[earth]] from [[space]], and earth's movement around the [[sun]]. ===Whem Ankh: The Cycle of Life in Ancient Egypt=== Whem Ankh is an exhibit displaying [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] from the daily life as lived on the banks of the lower [[Nile River]] 2,200 years ago. Over 250 artifacts are included in the collection, including the [[mummies]] of Nes-hor and of Nes-min, [[priests]] in the [[temple]] of the [[Egypt]]ian [[fertility]] god [[Min (god)|Min]], and the [[coffin]] of Djed-hor-ef-ankh. ===Marchand Hall of Wildflowers=== The Marchand Hall of [[Wildflowers]] displays several species of [[plant]] life collected throughout several years by [[naturalists]] George and Paul Marchand. ===Gems and Minerals=== [[Gemstone|Gems]] and [[minerals]] is an exhibit exploring [[crystal]] structure and [[chemical]] composition of the mineral heritage of [[Western New York]], [[New York State]], and [[Ontario]]. ===Zoology=== [[Zoology]] is an exhibit exploring birds, mammals, [[reptiles]], and [[amphibians]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.sciencebuff.org/ The Buffalo Museum of Science homepage] * [http://www.gyroscopeinc.com/buffalo.html The Buffalo Museum of Science Master Plan] * [http://www.astc.org/ The Association of Science-Technology Centers (ASTC)] * [http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/preserveourplanet/ National Geographic] {{Buffalo(NY)}} {{coord|42.906132|N|78.843314|W|display=title}} [[Category:Science museums in New York]] [[Category:Natural history museums in New York]] [[Category:Museums in Buffalo, New York]] [[Category:Institutions accredited by the American Alliance of Museums]] [[Category:1861 establishments in New York]] [[Category:Museums established in 1861]] {{ErieCountyNY-geo-stub}} {{US-museum-stub}}
